metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Arrays are used to store multiple values of the same type in a single variable, instead of declaring separate variables for each value.
content.html: Arrays are used to store multiple values of the same type in a single variable, instead of declaring separate variables for each value.

content.text: In Go, there are two ways to declare an array:
content.html: In Go, there are two ways to declare an array:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var array_name =  [length]datatype{values} // here length is defined
        or
      var array_name = [...]datatype{values} // here length is inferred

content.code:
var array_name =  [length]datatype{values} // here length is defined
or
var array_name = [...]datatype{values} // here length is inferred

syntax_highlighting.text:
var array_name =  [length]datatype{values} // here length is defined
 or
 var array_name = [...]datatype{values} // here length is inferred

content.code_html:
var array_name = [length]datatype{values} // here length is defined
or

var array_name = [...]datatype{values} // here length is inferred

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var array_name =  [length]datatype{values} // here length is defined
        or
      var array_name = [...]datatype{values} // here length is inferred

syntaxHighlighting.text:
array_name := [length]datatype{values} // here length 
        is definedor array_name := [...]datatype{values} // 
        here length is inferred

content.code:
array_name := [length]datatype{values} // here length
is definedor array_name := [...]datatype{values} //
here length is inferred

syntax_highlighting.text:
array_name := [length]datatype{values} // here length 
        is definedor array_name := [...]datatype{values} // 
        here length is inferred

content.code_html:
array_name := [length]datatype{values} // here length is defined

or

array_name := [...]datatype{values} // here length is inferred

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
array_name := [length]datatype{values} // here length 
        is definedor array_name := [...]datatype{values} // 
        here length is inferred

content.text: Note: The length specifies the number of elements to store in the array. In Go, arrays have a fixed length. The length of the array is either defined by a number or is inferred (means that the compiler decides the length of the array, based on the number of values ).
content.html: Note: The length specifies the number of elements to store in the array. In Go, arrays have a fixed length. The length of the array is either defined by a number or is inferred (means that the compiler decides the length of the array, based on the number of values).

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var arr1 = [3]int{1,2,3}
  arr2 := [5]int{4,5,6,7,8}

  fmt.Println(arr1)
  fmt.Println(arr2)
}

package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var arr1 = [...]int{1,2,3}
  arr2 := [...]int{4,5,6,7,8}

  fmt.Println(arr1)
  fmt.Println(arr2)
}

package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var cars = [4]string{"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"}
  fmt.Print(cars)
}

content.text: You can access a specific array element by referring to the index number.
content.html: You can access a specific array element by referring to the index number.

content.text: In Go, array indexes start at 0. That means that [0] is the first element, [1] is the second element, etc.
content.html: In Go, array indexes start at 0. That means that [0] is the first element, [1] is the second element, etc.

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  prices := [3]int{10,20,30}

  fmt.Println(prices[0])
  fmt.Println(prices[2])
}

content.text: You can also change the value of a specific array element by referring to the index number.
content.html: You can also change the value of a specific array element by referring to the index number.

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  prices := [3]int{10,20,30}

  prices[2] = 50
  fmt.Println(prices)
}

content.text: If an array or one of its elements has not been initialized in the code, it is assigned the default value of its type.
content.html: If an array or one of its elements has not been initialized in the code, it is assigned the default value of its type.

content.text: Tip: The default value for int is 0, and the default value for string is "".
content.html: Tip: The default value for int is 0, and the default value for string is "".

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  arr1 := [5]int{} //not initialized
   arr2 := [5]int{1,2} //partially initialized
   arr3 := [5]int{1,2,3,4,5} //fully initialized
  fmt.Println(arr1)
  fmt.Println(arr2)
  fmt.Println(arr3)
}

content.text: It is possible to initialize only specific elements in an array.
content.html: It is possible to initialize only specific elements in an array.

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  arr1 := [5]int{1:10,2:40}

  fmt.Println(arr1)
}

content.text: Find the Length of an Array
The len() function is used to find the length of an array:
content.html: The len() function is used to find the length of an array:

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  arr1 := [4]string{"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"}
  arr2 := [...]int{1,2,3,4,5,6}

  fmt.Println(len(arr1))
  fmt.Println(len(arr2))
}

content.text: Create an array, named cars, of type string:
content.html: Create an array, named cars, of type string:

content.code_html:
package main   
import ("fmt") 

func main() {
  var  = [4]{"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"}
  fmt.Print()
}
